dek: A photographic tour of Brooklyn's literary scene, including bookstores, bars, restaurants, performance venues, parks, coffee shops and landmarks throughout Park Slope, Cobble Hill, Boerum Hill, Carroll Gardens, Fort Greene, Williamsburg, Greenpoint and Gowanus.

items.caption: Recently renovated into a bright and compulsively browsable place, [this Cobble Hill mainstay](http://www.bookcourt.org/) is a required whistle-stop for New York writers from Cecily von Ziegesar, author of the Gossip Girl series, to debut novelist Teju Cole. Jonathan Ames had a knife-throwing demonstration here once—as dramatized on his HBO show _Bored to Death_ (163 Court St.; 718-875-3677).
**[PowerHouse Arena](http://www.powerhousearena.com/)** is a lofty and beautiful gallery/bookstore as well as a publisher—one of a few upstart bookshops in DUMBO (37 Main St.; 718-666-3049).
Tiny **[Melville House](http://mhpbooks.com/)** has a little storefront—possibly the only shop in New York devoted exclusively to independent presses (145 Plymouth St.; 718-722-9204).

**[P.S. Bookshop](http://www.psbnyc.com/)** isn’t affiliated with a publisher but offers one of the borough’s most comprehensive selections of used books—in a new, larger location—and is definitely worth a lengthy browse (76 Front St.; 718-222-3340).

The view from [this walk](http://nyharborparks.org/visit/brhe.html) overlooking the East River, just south of the Brooklyn Bridge, between Orange and Remsen streets, is so stunning that it’s easy to forget to look the other way for a peek into the necklace of beautiful, expensive brownstones lining the walk. One of them, near Pineapple Street, houses the nautically themed duplex that Norman Mailer once called home.

This [Georgian-style](http://www.nycgovparks.org/parks/Cobble%20Hill%20Park/) gem alongside a weathered cobbled street was one of New York’s first vest-pocket parks. It’s become such an icon of bohemian-bourgeois Brooklyn that it was featured in the 2009 Broadway play _God of Carnage,_ about snobbish urbanites with a dark side (now adapted into a movie starring Kate Winslet). Grab a sandwich on multi-grain at Ted & Honey, on the southeast corner, and sit for a spell toward the west end of the park, watching budding writers at play in the sandbox (Congress St. between Clinton and Henry Sts.).

Arthur Phillips (author of _Prague_ and _The Tragedy of Arthur_) writes at **[Tazza](http://tazzabklyn.com/)**, imbibes at **[Floyd, NY](http://floydny.com/)** (pictured)—“it’s got a cool boccie court” (131 Atlantic Ave.)—and takes his dogs out for play dates in the dog run at Pier 6, a brand-new waterfront park at the western end of Atlantic Avenue.

Red Hook’s Korean-influenced **[The Good Fork](http://www.goodfork.com/)** “has really good food," says Kurt Andersen, critic, radio host, and author of _Turn of the Century_, and it’s not annoyingly locavorish” (391 Van Brunt St.; 718-643-6636; entrées from $13). Not too far away, Andersen still gets a kick out of the dive bar **Montero**—a holdover from Cobble Hill’s longshoreman days—where he and friends are always “in the minority of being non-alcoholics” (73 Atlantic Ave.).

“I like Gowanus,” says _Lowboy_ author John Wray, of the neighborhood surrounding the canal between Park Slope and Carroll Gardens. “It runs the gamut from places to drink to places to see performances, even a climbing gym”—**[Brooklyn Boulders](http://www.brooklynboulders.com/)** (575 Degraw St.; 347-834-9066).

Wray is also a fan of the bar **[Littlefield](http://www.littlefieldnyc.com/)** (pictured), where Kristen Schaal, a _Daily Show_ regular, co-hosts a “very funny comedy show” called Hot Tub (622 Degraw St.). Wray buys the occasional pair of socks at the **[Brooklyn Circus](http://thebkcircus.com/)**, “run by these guys who dress like Outkast—they’re so goddamn dapper” (150 Nevins St.; 718-222-9772).

It’s one thing for a [bookstore](http://communitybookstore.net/) to survive for 40 years, another for its anniversary celebration to be attended by Paul Auster and Jonathan Safran Foer, who placed their own recommendations on the front sales rack. An object of great local loyalty, Community—the granddaddy of independent bookstores—is modern but cozy, with overstuffed chairs and a lizard in a terrarium out back for the kids (143 Seventh Ave.; 718-783-3075).

Like the neighborhood, [this coffee shop](http://www.tealoungeny.com/) is large but feels neighborly and intimate. In its warm semi-darkness, surrounded by local artwork, everyone from freelancers to toddlers and nannies seems to get along. The food is heavy on hummus and veggies (837 Union St.).

Dave Eggers, author of _A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius, _fled Brooklyn long ago, but he left behind [826NYC](http://www.superherosupplies.com/), which tutors underprivileged kids in writing. Everything sold in this very odd store—sidekick capes, secret-identity kits, cans of “omnipotence”—benefits the group. It is run by volunteers, so the hours are irregular; call ahead (372 Fifth Ave.; 718-499-9884).

Reconstructed from a 1699 Dutch farmhouse that played a key role in the Revolutionary War, the [Old Stone House](http://theoldstonehouse.org/) is now a museum. Once a month you can hear up-and-coming Brooklyn writers discuss themes ranging from “Make Mine a Double”—on women and drinking—to books by war veterans (336 Third St.; 718-768-3195).

Okay, so nothing can quite match the glory of the New York Public Library’s main branch in Midtown Manhattan. But [Brooklyn’s own main branch](http://www.brooklynpubliclibrary.org/locations/central), beside the northwest entrance to Prospect Park, runs a close second for both its architectural grandeur (it’s an Art Deco masterpiece) and its vast holdings (10 Grand Army Plaza; 718-230-2100).

“An excellent restaurant, probably the best in the neighborhood, is **[Al di là Trattoria](http://www.aldilatrattoria.com/)**," says Paul Auster, author of _The New York Trilogy_ and _The Brooklyn Follies_ and godfather of the Brooklyn literary scene. Go during the week, though: The Northern Italian place gets so busy that even Auster can’t always get a table (248 Fifth Ave.; 718-783-4565; entrées from $17). He and novelist-wife Siri Hustvedt often just pick up groceries at [Blue Apron Foods](http://blue-apron-foods.com/): “Good cheese, cold cuts, smoked fish—lovely things” (812 Union St.; 718-230-3180).

“This will probably get me hate mail,” says Darin Strauss, author of _Chang and Eng_ and _Half a Life,_ “but I actually like the **[Park Slope Barnes & Noble](http://store-locator.barnesandnoble.com/store/2876)**. The lower-floor book area is a play room”—with stroller parking—“so it’s fun to take your kids”


(267 Seventh Ave.; 718-832-9066).

Strauss also frequents **[Perch Cafe](http://www.theperchcafe.com/)** and **[Barbès](http://barbesbrooklyn.com/)** but works at **[Brooklyn Commune](http://www.brooklyncommune.com/) **(pictured) at the south end of Prospect Park, and swears by their tempeh sandwich (601 Greenwood Ave.; 718-686-1044).

Kathryn Harrison (author of _The Kiss_ and the forthcoming _Enchantments_) has a few Park Slope favorites, including the simple pleasures like **Botanica Universal**, which sells religious goods “such as un-hexing powder to protect you from your enemies. Vaguely menacing people shop there” (376 Fifth Ave.; 718-832-3606). Mediterranean market **[D’Vine Taste](http://dvine-taste.com/)** has “amazing baba ghanoush” (150 Seventh Ave.; 718-369-9548). And at the **[Brooklyn Botanic Garden’s Bonsai Museum](http://www.bbg.org/discover/gardens/bonsai_museum/) **(pictured) in fall, “the maple leaves turn—leaves the size of my smallest fingernail. I’m bewitched by them” (718-623-7200).

Long before Fort Greene was gentrified, the Brooklyn Academy of Music was the neighborhood’s anchor and greatest Manhattanite draw. The beautifully renovated building now hosts not only theater, dance, and movie events, but its glamorous BAMcafé also offers the best-value literary dinner in town. [Eat, Drink & Be Literary](http://www.bam.org/view.aspx?pid=277) features unlimited food and wine and an interview with a writer, all for $50—upcoming guests range from Sapphire to Russell Banks to Ann Patchett (30 Lafayette Ave.; 718-623-7811; check bam.org for the schedule).

Susan Choi, author of _A Person of Interest_, has a few top picks in the Fort Greene neighborhood, starting with **[Urban Vintage](http://urbanvintageny.com/Welcome.html)** (pictured, 294 Grand Ave.; 718-783-6045), which is not a clothing store but rather “the best place to nurse a caffeinated beverage and work all day long.” **[Der Schwarze Kölner](http://www.ex49.com/dsk/)** (710 Fulton St.), on the other hand, is “the best place to drink beer and gossip after a reading at **[Greenlight](http://greenlightbookstore.com/)**” . On bright days, Choi recommends hilly, spacious Fort Greene Park, the ideal setting for a “dirt-cheap picnic” of tacos from the **Jalapeno NYC** taco truck that’s nearby on weekends (DeKalb Ave. at Cumberland St.).

Greenpoint—Williamsburg’s cheaper, homier neighbor to the north—may have more writers than its hipper cousin; it certainly has the better bookstore. [Word’s](http://wordbrooklyn.com/) books are perfectly curated and its proprietors always friendly, right down to the witty notes accompanying staff members’ recommended lists. If you happen upon a reading or a launch party, you’ll be welcomed with open arms—and possibly with pizza (126 Franklin St.; 718-383-0096).

In case you still think comics are the exclusive province of pudgy nerds, here’s the ultimate corrective, a spot brimming with eye candy that ranges from true rarities wrapped in plastic to the simplest children’s books and the very best of graphic fiction and memoir. [Desert Island](http://www.desertislandbrooklyn.com/) takes its comics seriously, but not too seriously. Even the decor—whimsical wallpaper and a mobile chandelier—is colorful, inviting, and gracefully hip (540 Metropolitan Ave.; 718-388-5087).

The railcar-like back room of this [festive watering hole](http://petescandystore.com/) is as busy as its vintage, slightly rockabilly decor. Whenever bands aren’t playing (the music ranges from banjos to psychedelia), there are quizzes, spelling bees, and all kinds of readings—separate series for poetry and prose—with few literary heroes left unrepresented. It’s a little younger than the crowds you’ll find in the bars of Park Slope or Cobble Hill, and runs later into the night (709 Lorimer St.; Pete’s Reading Series on alternate Thursdays).

Though this [all-purpose café/restaurant](http://roeblingtearoom.com/)—two blocks removed from the insane bustle of Bedford Avenue—happens to have one of the best comfort-food menus in the area (think pork chops and polenta, or tagliatelle with clams), it’s also ideal for daytime scribbling. High ceilings, ample seating, and a strong list of energizing beverages make it very popular with those neighborhood artists who gravitate more to language and less to the art of being cooler than one’s neighbor (143 Roebling St.; 718-963-0760; entrées from $14).

Locals started mocking [Brooklyn’s newest boutique hotel](http://www.hwbrooklyn.com/) months before it opened. Take that as a seal of approval. Sip artisanal coffee in the lobby, play some vinyl on your room’s vintage-look record player, and take in the Manhattan view from the rooftop bar. It’s a fairly accurate sampling of the latest, most gentrified incarnation of Williamsburg life (718-218-7500; doubles from $295).
